conclusion: To determine the temperature of State C, use the ideal gas law and properties of the thermodynamic processes.
The ideal gas law states PV = nRT.
Process AB is an isochoric process with volume V_A = V_B = V_1 and pressure changes from P_1 to P_2.
Using the ideal gas law for State A: P_1 V_1 = n R T_0.
For State B, since the volume remains the same: P_2 V_1 = n R T_B.
Dividing the equation for State B by the equation for State A gives T_B = T_0 (P_2/P_1).
Process BC is an isobaric process with pressure P_B = P_C = P_2 and volume changes from V_1 to V_2.
Using the ideal gas law for State B: P_2 V_1 = n R T_B.
For State C: P_2 V_2 = n R T_C.
Dividing the equation for State C by the equation for State B gives T_C = T_B (V_2/V_1).
Substitute T_B from Step 2 to find T_C = T_0 (P_2/P_1) (V_2/V_1).
The temperature of State C is T_0 (P_2/P_1) (V_2/V_1).
